entity_name: J. C. King, Chief, Western Hemisphere Division
summary: J. C. King was the Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division. The documents available suggest his involvement in overseeing and coordinating various operations related to Cuba and Latin America during the early 1960s. These operations included FI-CI activity, propaganda efforts, political action, paramilitary activities, training, communications, and support. He was also involved in planning to exploit Khrushchev's visit to Cuba and was the sender of a memorandum detailing a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico. The documents indicate his role in managing and reporting on sensitive intelligence and operational matters within the Western Hemisphere.
key_connections: Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico
significance: Based on the available documents, J. C. King's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as a high-ranking CIA official overseeing operations in the Western Hemisphere, particularly those related to Cuba. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, his involvement in covert activities and intelligence gathering in the region during this period places him within the broader context of US-Cuban relations and CIA operations that are often scrutinized in relation to the assassination.
